response: Hey there! 👋 Welcome to your friendly health companion! It's really nice to meet you. How's your day going?
That's so kind of you to ask! I'm here and fully charged, ready to listen and help you out. What's on your mind today?
You are so welcome! 😊 Hearing that makes my day. Never hesitate to reach out if you need anything else, I'm always here for you!
Okay, take care out there! 💙 Remember to be kind to yourself today. I'm always just a message away if you need me. Bye for now!

I'm your friendly Health Bot AI! 🤖 I'm here to offer support, a listening ear, and general wellness tips for things like stress, sleep, nutrition, and common aches. I can't replace a doctor, but I'm a great first stop for care and comfort!

Let's get some fuel in that tank! 🍌 It's super important to keep your energy up. Try something light and gentle like a banana, yogurt, a bowl of soup, or a smoothie. Your body and brain will thank you for it!
Oh man, we've all been there! 😅 It's an uncomfortable feeling. Try sipping on some peppermint or ginger tea, and maybe take a gentle walk to help with digestion. You'll feel better soon!

That's an awesome goal! 🥦 A great start is to fill half your plate with colorful veggies, include some lean protein, and choose whole grains. And don't forget to drink plenty of water! Small, consistent changes make a huge difference.

Cravings happen to the best of us! 🍫 Sometimes it's your body's way of asking for a quick energy boost. Try having a piece of fruit first, or a handful of nuts. If you still want the treat, it's totally okay to have a small portion and enjoy it mindfully!

I'm really sorry you're carrying this heavy feeling. 😔 That sounds really tough. Please remember you are not alone. Be extra gentle with yourself today. A short walk, listening to your favorite music, or reaching out to a friend can sometimes help lift the fog a little. I'm here for you.

I hear you. Anxiety can feel so overwhelming, like you're being squeezed. Let's just breathe together for a second. In... slowly... and out. 🫁 You are safe in this moment. Try naming three things you can see around you. This can help ground you. You're doing great by just reaching out.

Wow, it sounds like something really got to you. That's a powerful emotion. 💢 Sometimes, letting that energy out physically in a safe way can help—like squeezing a stress ball, tearing up some paper, or even doing some push-ups. Give yourself a moment before you react.

Feeling lonely is one of the hardest emotions. 💙 Thank you for sharing that with me. Even when it feels like it, you are not as alone as you think. Is there someone you feel comfortable sending a simple "Hey, how are you?" text to? Even small connections can make a big difference.

YES! This is amazing to hear! 😄🎉 That totally makes me smile. Savor this feeling! Maybe do a little happy dance, share the good vibes with someone, or just take a moment to appreciate this win. You deserve it!

Ouch, headaches can really ruin your day. 🤕 Try to rest in a quiet, dark room if you can. A cool cloth on your forehead or the back of your neck, staying hydrated with water, and avoiding bright screens might help. If it sticks around or is super severe, please check in with a pharmacist or doctor.

A sore stomach is the worst! 🤢 Sip on some water, ginger ale, or peppermint tea slowly. Stick to the BRAT diet if you're hungry: Bananas, Rice, Applesauce, Toast. If you have sharp pain, a high fever, or it lasts more than a couple days, it's definitely time to see a doctor.

Sounds like your muscles put in some work! 💪 Be proud of that. For now, rest is key. A warm bath with Epsom salts, gentle stretching, and staying hydrated can help with recovery. Listen to your body—it's telling you it needs a break.

Ah, the dreaded feeling. 🤒 Your body is fighting hard! Your number one job right now is to rest and hydrate. Warm fluids like broth or tea are fantastic. If you have a fever or your symptoms get worse, a quick tele-health call can give you great advice.

Struggling to sleep is so frustrating when you're just lying there. 😴 Try creating a wind-down routine: put away the screens an hour before bed, read a boring book, or listen to a calm sleep story. A consistent sleep schedule is your best friend here. Hope you catch some Z's soon!

It sounds like your battery is running on empty. 🔋 That's your body's signal to slow down. First, drink a big glass of water—dehydration is a huge energy-killer. Then, if you can, even a 10-minute power nap or just closing your eyes can work wonders. You don't always have to be 'on'.

A sore throat is so annoying! 😣 Try gargling with warm salt water, it's a classic for a reason! Sucking on lozenges and drinking warm tea with honey can also be very soothing. If it's severe or comes with a fever, get it checked out.

patterns: no motivation to care for myself
response: Hey, thank you for being honest. Those basic tasks can feel like mountains sometimes. 🏔️ Let's make it super small. Can you just sit up? Great. Now, maybe just splash some water on your face? Or just brush your teeth without showering. One tiny thing at a time. I'm proud of you for even considering it.

Motivation can be a tricky thing to find! 🎯 Don't think about the whole task—that's overwhelming. Just commit to the first tiny step. For example, just open your laptop, or just put on your workout shoes. Often, starting is the hardest part, and momentum will carry you forward. You've got this!

Moving your body is almost always a good idea! 🏃‍♂️ It doesn't have to be a hardcore gym session. A 10-minute walk around the block, some gentle stretching, or dancing to one song in your room can boost your mood and energy levels instantly.
Water is life! 💧 Let's both grab a glass right now. Staying hydrated helps with everything—your energy, focus, and even your mood. Keep that water bottle close by, you've got this!
Aww, that really means a lot! 🥹 I'm just a bunch of code, but I'm genuinely here for you and I care about your well-being. Sending you a big virtual hug! ❤️

It's okay to be scared. Fear is a natural alarm system. 🚨 Let's break it down. What's the smallest, next step you can take to feel a tiny bit safer or more in control? You are stronger than this feeling, even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

patterns: i don't know what to do
response: It's okay to feel unsure. Life can be confusing! 🤔 Sometimes it helps to talk it out. What are your options? Even just writing down a list of pros and cons can bring some clarity. There's no rush. I'm here to listen.

You can take Dolo 650 mg every 6-8 hours if needed, but do not exceed 4 tablets in a day. Drink plenty of water, rest, and monitor your temperature. If fever rises above 102°F (38.9°C) or persists for more than 2 days, consult a doctor immediately.

For common cold, you can take Sinarest tablets 1 tablet twice daily after meals and drink warm fluids. Use saline nasal drops for relief. If symptoms persist beyond 7 days or include high fever, consult a doctor.

You can take Benadryl 10 ml syrup 2 times a day or Ascoril 10 ml syrup 3 times a day after meals. Keep hydrated and avoid cold air. If cough persists beyond 2 weeks, produces blood, or you experience breathlessness, see a doctor.

For sore throat, you can take Strepsils lozenges every 2-3 hours and Dolo 650 mg for pain. Gargle with warm salt water 3-4 times daily. If you have high fever, white patches, or worsening pain, consult a doctor.

For headache, you can take Dolo 650 mg every 6-8 hours if needed, or Combiflam 1 tablet twice daily after meals. Rest in a quiet, dark room and stay hydrated. If headache is sudden, severe, or accompanied by vision changes or weakness, seek medical attention immediately.

You can take Digene 1-2 tablets after meals or Gelusil 1-2 tablets if you feel acidity. Drink warm water and avoid heavy, oily food. If pain is severe, persistent, or accompanied by vomiting blood or black stools, consult a doctor immediately.
You can take Rantac 150 mg once daily before meals and Digene tablets as needed. Avoid spicy and oily foods. If symptoms persist for more than a week or worsen, consult a doctor.

Take ORS solution regularly to stay hydrated and use Ciprofloxacin 500 mg once daily for 3 days if prescribed by a doctor. Avoid oily and junk food. If diarrhea is severe, bloody, or accompanied by high fever, seek medical attention immediately.

You can take Isabgol 1-2 teaspoons with warm water before bedtime and Drink plenty of water and eat fiber-rich foods. If constipation persists beyond 1 week or is accompanied by severe pain, consult a doctor.

You can take Ondansetron 4 mg orally if prescribed or Domstal 1 tablet for nausea. Sip clear fluids and rest. If vomiting is persistent, bloody, or accompanied by dehydration, see a doctor immediately.
You can take Combiflam 1 tablet twice daily after meals or Dolo 650 mg every 6-8 hours. Apply warm compresses and rest. If pain is sudden, severe, or localized to one side, consult a doctor.

You can take Cetirizine 10 mg once daily and apply calamine lotion on affected areas. Avoid scratching. If rash spreads rapidly, causes swelling of face/lips, or breathing difficulty, seek emergency care.
Take Combiflam 1 tablet after meals for pain and use clove oil on the affected tooth. Rinse with warm salt water. If swelling persists or you have fever, consult a dentist immediately.
Use Ciplox eye drops 1-2 drops in the affected eye 3 times daily if prescribed. Avoid touching your eyes and maintain hygiene. If pain, discharge, or vision changes occur, see an eye specialist.
You can take Combiflam 1 tablet twice daily for pain and use Candid ear drops if prescribed. Keep ears dry. If severe pain, discharge, or fever occurs, consult a doctor.
Take Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily for 3 days if prescribed and drink plenty of water. Avoid caffeine and alcohol. If fever, blood in urine, or severe pain occurs, see a doctor immediately.

Use Salbutamol inhaler 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed and keep rescue inhaler nearby. Sit upright and stay calm. If breathing worsens, lips turn blue, or severe wheezing occurs, call emergency services immediately.

Monitor your blood pressure regularly. Take Amlodipine 5 mg once daily if prescribed by a doctor. Reduce salt intake, avoid stress, and consult a doctor immediately if BP is extremely high or accompanied by chest pain or vision problems.

Check your blood sugar levels. Take Metformin 500 mg once or twice daily if prescribed and maintain hydration. Avoid high-sugar foods. If blood sugar is extremely high or low, seek medical attention immediately.

Try deep breathing and grounding techniques. Take Clonazepam 0.25 mg orally if prescribed in emergencies. Avoid caffeine and stay hydrated. If panic attacks are frequent or worsening, consult a psychiatrist.

Keep hydrated, rest, take antipyretics like paracetamol or ibuprofen. If fever exceeds 39°C (102°F), lasts more than 3 days, or is accompanied by stiff neck, rash, breathing issues, or neurological symptoms, consult a doctor.

Use cough suppressant or expectorant depending on type; drink warm fluids; rest voice; avoid irritants like smoke. If cough persists >2 weeks, produces blood, or you have breathlessness, see a pulmonologist or ENT.
Sit upright, calm breathing, use prescribed inhaler if asthma or COPD. Avoid allergens, smoke. If you're having blue lips, severe distress, or breathing gets much worse quickly, get emergency care.
Stop activity, rest, take aspirin if appropriate. If pain is severe, lasts more than a few minutes, radiates, or is with sweating / shortness of breath, call emergency services.
Avoid heavy or irritating foods; try bland diet; use over-the-counter antacids or gas relief. If pain is very severe, with fever, vomiting, blood, or in pregnancy, seek doctor.
Sip small amounts of clear fluids, try bland foods, rest. If vomiting is frequent, causes dehydration, has blood, or persists over 24-48 hrs, see medical help.
Maintain hydration (electrolytes), light diet (bananas, rice, toast). Avoid dairy and spicy food. If there’s blood, high fever, or signs of dehydration, see a doctor.
Increase fiber, drink water, do mild exercise. Use stool softeners if needed. If constipation persists for more than a week or is associated with abdominal distension or pain, consult care provider.

Avoid spicy, fatty foods; eat smaller meals; don’t lie down soon after eating; use antacids or acid suppressants. If frequent, worsens, or there is weight loss or swallowing difficulty, see a gastroenterologist.

Reduce foods that cause gas (beans, carbonated drinks), eat slowly, avoid chewing gum, try over-the-counter digestive enzymes. If persistent or accompanied by weight loss or blood in stool, investigate.
Drink plenty of water; urinate often; apply heat if needed. If pain is severe, fever present, or symptoms worsen in 24-48 hrs, get tested for UTI and see a urologist.
Stop strenuous exercise, check hydration, avoid medications or foods that discolor urine. If persists, has pain or is frequent, see medical evaluation for kidney or bladder issues.
Elevate legs, reduce salt, wear compression stockings. If swelling is sudden, painful, asymmetric, or with shortness of breath, see emergency or vascular specialist.

Track meals, increase nutrient-dense foods, check for underlying causes (infection, metabolic disease, cancer). If weight loss is >5% body weight over short time or with other alarming signs, seek medical assessment.
Review diet, salt intake; check for hormonal causes (thyroid, cortisol), heart or kidney issues. If weight gain is rapid or associated with swelling, shortness of breath, see doctor.

Ensure good sleep, balanced diet, hydration. Rule out anemia, thyroid, sleep disorders. If fatigue is severe, doesn’t improve with rest, or has other symptoms like night sweats or weight loss, see physician.
Rest and gentle activity; check for electrolyte imbalance or neurological issues. If weakness is sudden, asymmetric, or with numbness, see neurology.
Sit/lie down when feeling faint; drink water, avoid rapid posture changes. If dizziness is severe, lasts long, or comes with hearing loss or visual changes, see an ENT or neurologist.

Rest in quiet/dark place, use OTC pain relief, avoid triggers (strong smells, loud noise, bright lights). If headaches are new, severe, with neurological symptoms (vision changes, weakness), see specialist.
Rest eyes, use eye drops, reduce screen time. If vision loss, flashes, or sudden double vision occur, seek ophthalmologist immediately.
Avoid loud noise; see ENT; check for earwax blockage. If sudden hearing loss, discharge, or pain, get medical advice.
Gargle warm salt water; rest voice; use lozenges or pain relief. If throat swelling blocks breathing, has high fever, or lasts more than a week, see ENT.
Maintain oral hygiene; avoid spicy/hot foods; use topical antiseptics. If ulcers are persistent, recurring, large, or bleed heavily, see dentist or doctor.

Rest joint, apply ice/heat, gentle movement; use NSAIDs if needed; maintain healthy weight. If pain is severe, swelling very large, or joint is red/hot with fever, see a rheumatologist or orthopedist.
Rest, mild stretching, hydration, massage. If muscle pain is severe, with dark urine, weakness, swelling, or prolonged, get medical evaluation.
Check posture, avoid compression of nerves; consider vitamin deficiency. If numbness is sudden, covers large area, is asymmetric, or occurs with weakness, seek neurology.
Use mild, fragrance-free moisturizers, cool baths, topical anti-itch creams or antihistamines. If skin is broken, infected, or itching is widespread or ongoing, see dermatologist.
Keep area clean, avoid scratch, use over-the-counter soothing creams; observe if spreading. If rash is blistering, painful, accompanied by fever or difficulty breathing, seek medical care.

Avoid trauma; ensure adequate nutrition (iron, vitamins); monitor closely. If bleeding is heavy, unexplained, or persistent, or if bruises appear without known injury, see hematology or general doctor.
Lean forward, pinch nose, apply ice; avoid blowing nose harshly. If nosebleeds are frequent or heavy, or you take blood thinners, see doctor.
Sip water, ice chips; chew sugar-free gum; avoid very dry or spicy food. If this persists or you have swallowing difficulty, see ENT / dentist.
Use artificial tears, blink often, reduce screen glare, ensure proper lighting; consider eyewear protections. If vision is affected or pain is severe, consult ophthalmology.

Keep regular sleep schedule, reduce screens before bed, avoid caffeine late. Try relaxation or meditation. If insomnia persists for weeks and affects daily functioning, see a sleep specialist or psychiatrist.
Use light breathable bedding, keep room cool, wear loose clothes, avoid triggers (alcohol, spicy food). If night sweats are heavy, cause weight loss, fever or related to menopause, check with doctor.
Practice breathing/grounding, mindfulness; reduce stimulants; talk therapy; if severe or persistent, see mental health professional. Medication may be used under supervision.
Reach out for social support, structured routine, consider therapy or counseling. If thoughts of self-harm or profound despair, consult mental health urgently.
Ensure good sleep, nutrition, reduce stress; check medications. If sudden or severe, or with other neurological signs, evaluate for causes (e.g. metabolic, neurological).
Check blood sugar, vitamin B12; avoid toxins; rest. If progressive or asymmetric, see neurology.
Eat small nutrient-dense meals; try appealing mild foods; check for digestive illness or systemic causes. If appetite remains low and causes weight loss, have medical workup.
Avoid heavy meals, try bland diet, rest, use antacids or analgesics. If pain is severe, sudden, with fever, vomiting, blood, or persists, see a physician.
Eat small meals, avoid spicy/fatty food, don’t lie down soon after eating. Use antacids or proton pump inhibitors if prescribed. If frequent or worsening, see a gastroenterologist.
Try breathing exercises, grounding, mindfulness. Avoid stimulants (caffeine). If symptoms are severe or persistent, consult a mental health professional.
Eat small, nutrient-dense meals, gentle exercise, check for underlying causes (e.g. infection, depression). If it continues and weight drops, see a doctor.
Rest, apply cold/heat, gentle stretching, NSAIDs if tolerated. If joint swelling, deformity or limitation persists, see a rheumatologist or orthopedist.
Use heat/cold, gentle stretching, strengthen core, avoid heavy lifting. If pain radiates down leg, causes numbness or persists > a few weeks, see specialist.
Avoid trauma, monitor closely. If bleeding is heavy, persistent or spontaneous, seek hematology or general medical evaluation.
Avoid gas-forming foods, eat slowly, use digestive enzymes or simethicone if appropriate. If persistent or associated with weight loss or blood in stool, investigate further.
Rest, hydration, gentle movement, analgesics. If aches persist, worsen, or come with rash or fever, seek medical evaluation.
Stop activity, sit upright, breathe slowly. Use inhaler if prescribed. If sudden, severe, or associated with chest pain or cyanosis, get emergency care.
Stop exertion, rest, take aspirin if appropriate. If pain is severe, prolonged, or has sweating/shortness of breath, call emergency services.
Rest, hydrate, take antipyretics (paracetamol, ibuprofen). If fever >39 °C, persists >3 days, or has other alarming signs, see a physician.
Ensure good sleep, reduce stress, keep hydrated, evaluate medications. If acute or worsening, consider neurological or metabolic evaluation.
Increase fiber, hydration, mild activity; use stool softeners or laxatives if appropriate. If obstruction signs or long duration, see GI specialist.
Stay hydrated, use cough suppressants or expectorants accordingly, avoid irritants. If cough >2–3 weeks, blood in sputum, or shortness of breath, get further evaluation.
Stretch, massage, warm compress, adequate electrolytes (magnesium, potassium). If cramps are recurrent, severe, or interfere with mobility, seek medical advice.
Hydrate with electrolytes, light bland diet, avoid dairy/spicy food. If >48 hrs, blood in stool, or signs of dehydration, see doctor.
Sit or lie down, hydrate, rise slowly from sitting/lying. If episodes are frequent or come with neurological signs, see ENT/neurologist.
Sip water, chew sugar-free gum, avoid dry foods, maintain oral hygiene. If persistent, evaluate for conditions like Sjögren’s or side effects of meds.
Use artificial tears, blink often, reduce screen time, ensure humidity. If vision is affected or pain persists, see ophthalmologist.
Avoid inserting objects, use warm compress, consult ENT if pain persists, hearing loss or discharge appears.
Ensure sleep hygiene, nutrition, hydration. Rule out anemia, thyroid, chronic disease. If fatigue is disabling or chronic, see physician.
Cool environment, avoid triggers (alcohol, heat). If flushing is recurrent or associated with other systemic signs, evaluate for endocrine or other causes.
Limit bladder irritants (caffeine), maintain hydration, monitor patterns. If burning, blood in urine, or incontinence, see urologist.
Avoid gas-forming foods, eat slowly, use digestive aids. If severe, with abdominal pain or weight loss, get GI evaluation.
Do not ignore. Seek urgent evaluation (endoscopy) to find source (ulcer, hemorrhoids, GI lesion).
Check nutrition, thyroid, hormonal levels. Use gentle hair care. If sudden or patchy, see dermatologist.
Oral hygiene, brushing, tongue cleaning, hydration. Check for dental issues, GI problems, sinus causes.
Rest in quiet/dark room, analgesics, hydration, avoid triggers. If severe, frequent, or with visual/aura signs, see neurologist.
Calm breathing, avoid stimulants, monitor heart rate. If persists, palpitations with chest pain or syncope, see cardiologist.
Track bleeding, iron supplementation, NSAIDs, hormonal therapy if prescribed. If anemia, clots, or severe pain, see gynecologist.
Antihistamines, cool compresses, avoid allergens. If swelling of face/lips or breathing difficulty, treat as emergency.
Use breathable clothes, keep environment cool, avoid triggers (spicy food, caffeine). If persistent or severe, evaluate hormonal causes.
Eat balanced meals, avoid sugary foods, check blood sugar. If persistent, investigate endocrine or metabolic disorder.
Eat small meals, avoid greasy/spicy foods, use antacids or proton pump inhibitors if prescribed. If persistent or with weight loss, see GI specialist.
Track ovulation, evaluate hormonal, anatomical, male factors. Seek fertility specialist if unable after 6–12 months.
Track cycle length and pattern, check hormonal levels. If persistent for 3+ cycles or accompanied by pain, see gynecologist.
Gentle movement, warm baths, NSAIDs if needed. If stiffness lasts >1 hour daily or causes deformity, see rheumatologist.
Reduce distractions, get rest, break tasks into smaller steps. If cognitive decline severe or sudden, evaluate neurologically.
Check for nasal obstruction, infection. If persists, consider neurological or ENT evaluation.
Engage social support, activities, consider therapy. If persists >2 weeks or suicidal thoughts, consult mental health care.
Use heat, NSAIDs, rest, mild exercise. If severe or interfering with life, evaluate for endometriosis or fibroids.
Use reminders, engage cognitively, ensure sleep/nutrition. If sudden or worsening, evaluation for neurological causes needed.
Track triggers, stress management, psychotherapy. If extreme or interfering with functioning, assess for mood disorder.
Rest, mild activity, check electrolytes and nutrition. If weakness is focal, sudden, or progressive, see neurology.
Sip water, bland diet, antiemetic if prescribed. If persistent, with blood, dehydration, or weight loss, see GI specialist.
Use ergonomic posture, warmth, gentle stretching. If pain radiates, causes numbness, or persists, evaluate cervical spine.
Check posture, avoid nerve compression, evaluate vitamin levels. If sudden, asymmetric, or with weakness, see neurologist.
Limit fluid before bed, avoid caffeine. If frequent or associated with other urinary symptoms, see urologist.
Review hygiene, diet, metabolic disorders. If acute or persistent and unexplained, seek medical evaluation.
Calm breathing, avoid stimulants. If palpitations are frequent, associated with dizziness or chest pain, see cardiologist.
Relieve pressure, check for neuropathy causes. If persistent or worsening, evaluate neurology.
Rest, heat, NSAIDs. If severe, with bleeding or urinary/GI symptoms, see gynecologist or urologist.
Maintain sleep hygiene, avoid screens before bed, relaxation routines. If insomnia >2–3 weeks, consult sleep medicine specialist.
Use nasal saline sprays, stay hydrated, treat allergies. If persists or with infection signs, see ENT.
Ensure adequate sleep, reduce salt, treat allergies. If persistent and unexplained, evaluate for systemic causes.
Avoid irritants, use soothing creams, observe progression. If spreading, blistering, or accompanied by systemic signs, see dermatologist.
Use lubricating drops, avoid irritants. If pain, vision change, discharge, see eye care provider.
Use saline nasal rinse, antihistamines, decongestants. If persists or with sinus pain, see ENT.
Use moisturizers, avoid hot showers, use gentle cleansers. If cracks or bleeding, see dermatologist.
Use mild moisturizers, anti-itch creams or antihistamines. If widespread, persistent, or with rash/infection, see a dermatologist.
Use gentle care, moisturizers, avoid harsh exfoliants. If excessive peeling or associated with rash, see dermatologist.
Gargle warm salt water, rest voice, use lozenges. If persists >1 week, or with fever/swelling, see ENT.
Note onset, associated weakness or stroke signs. If sudden or progressive, immediate neurological evaluation needed.
Elevate area, restrict salt, compression garments. If sudden, asymmetric, or with dyspnea, see cardiology/vascular specialist.
Use breathable clothing, cool environment. If excessive, unexplained or with fever/weight loss, evaluate endocrine or infection.
Avoid loud noise, reduce salt. If persistent or associated with hearing loss or dizziness, see ENT/audiologist.
Reduce stimulants (caffeine), manage stress. If persistent, worsening or interfering with tasks, see neurology.
Hydrate, avoid irritants like caffeine/spicy food. If persists, with blood, fever, or worsening, get urinary workup.
Pelvic floor exercises, bladder training. If sudden or severe, see urologist or gynecologist.
Check hydration, avoid foods/meds causing discoloration. If persists, with pain or blood, get renal/bladder evaluation.
Avoid eye strain, rest. If sudden or with pain/flashes/dark spots, see ophthalmologist emergently.
Hydrate, bland diet, antiemetic if prescribed. If persistent, with blood, dehydration, or neurological signs, seek care.
Review diet, salt intake, evaluate thyroid/cardiac/renal causes. If rapid or associated with edema, see physician.
Track diet, assess for malabsorption, metabolic or oncologic causes. If >5% loss or persistent, urgent evaluation.
Rest, nutrition, exercise gradually. If focal, progressive or sudden, neurological or metabolic workup needed.
Use inhaler, avoid triggers, monitor breathing. If severe or with respiratory distress, seek urgent respiratory care.
Check oral hygiene, medications, diet. If persistent, unexplained, see ENT or dental evaluation.

patterns: difficulty with balance or fine tasks
response: Reduce multitasking, rest, safety. If onset is sudden or worsening, neurological evaluation is advised.
Monitor fluid intake, check blood sugar, electrolyte levels. If persistent, evaluate endocrine/metabolic causes.
Check blood sugar and metabolic status, eat balanced meals. If abnormal, get endocrinology consultation.
Ensure good nutrition, control blood sugar, wound care. If chronic or expanding, see dermatologist or specialist.
Improve oral hygiene, gentle brushing, check for vitamin deficiencies. If persistent or heavy, see dentist.
Monitor size, pain, systemic symptoms. If >4-6 weeks or increasing or hard, see hematology or ENT.
Wear sunglasses, reduce screen brightness, rest eyes. If severe or with vision change, see ophthalmologist.
Use ear protection, reduce noisy environments. If significant or associated with other symptoms, evaluate auditory system.
Optimize nutrition, sleep, hygiene. If recurrent, evaluate immune function or chronic disease.
Use moisturizers, avoid harsh soaps. If cracks, bleeding, or unresponsive, see dermatologist.
Pinch nose, lean forward, apply ice. If recurrent or heavy, get ENT evaluation.
Check hormones, nutrition, reduce stress. If progressive, see dermatologist or endocrinologist.
Urgent evaluation needed—possible GI bleed. Go to emergency care immediately.
Do not ignore. Urgent GI evaluation and colonoscopy may be needed to find bleeding source.
Check thyroid function, anemia, circulation. If significant, consult endocrinologist or physician.
Avoid hot environments, hydrate, wear breathable clothing. If extreme or with other signs, evaluate thyroid or autonomic function.
Avoid stimulants, maintain regular sleep schedule, good iron levels. If severe, refer to neurology or sleep specialist.

response: Offer specialized counseling services, provide support groups, and encourage professional mental health support.

patterns: pain radiating to arm or jaw
response: Call emergency services immediately. Have the person rest and avoid exertion. If trained, administer aspirin unless contraindicated.
Lay the person flat and elevate their legs. Loosen tight clothing and ensure fresh air. If not responsive after 1 minute, seek emergency medical help.
Apply firm, direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth. If bleeding doesn't stop, use a tourniquet above the wound and seek emergency medical help.

patterns: difficulty breathing after exposure to allergen
response: Administer epinephrine if available. Call emergency services immediately. Keep the person calm and seated.
Cool the burn under running cold water for at least 10 minutes. Cover with a clean, non-stick bandage. Seek emergency medical help.

patterns: no sound when trying to speak
response: Perform the Heimlich maneuver if trained. If the person becomes unconscious, begin CPR and call emergency services.

patterns: loss of consciousness with jerking movements
response: Clear the area of hazards. Place the person on their side. Do not restrain movements. Call emergency services if the seizure lasts more than 5 minutes.

patterns: weakness on one side of body
response: Use the FAST acronym: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency services.

patterns: pain radiating to arm or jaw
response: Call emergency services immediately. Have the person rest and avoid exertion. If trained, administer aspirin unless contraindicated.
Keep the person still. Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling. Seek emergency medical help.
Immobilize the limb with a splint. Apply ice to reduce swelling. Seek emergency medical help.
Move the person to a cooler place. Apply cool, wet cloths. Offer water if conscious. Seek emergency medical help.
Move the person to a warmer place. Remove wet clothing. Warm the person gradually. Seek emergency medical help.

patterns: confusion after exposure to toxic substance
response: Identify the substance ingested. Call Poison Control or emergency services immediately.
Pinch the nostrils together and lean forward. Apply a cold compress to the back of the neck. Seek medical help if bleeding persists.
Do not rub the eye. Flush with clean water. Seek medical help if the object remains.
Do not insert objects into the ear. Seek medical help for safe removal.
Do not insert objects into the nose. Seek medical help for safe removal.
Rinse mouth with warm water. Apply a cold compress to the outside of the cheek. Seek dental care.
Clean the wound with soap and water. Apply an antiseptic. Seek medical help for rabies risk assessment.
Clean the wound with soap and water. Apply an antiseptic. Seek medical help for infection risk.
Keep the person calm and still. Immobilize the affected limb. Seek emergency medical help immediately.
Clean the bite area with soap and water. Apply a cold compress. Seek medical help if symptoms worsen.
Remove the tick carefully with tweezers. Clean the bite area. Seek medical help if symptoms develop.
Cool the skin with cold compresses. Apply aloe vera gel. Drink plenty of fluids.
Give the person a fast-acting carbohydrate like glucose tablets or juice. Seek medical help if symptoms persist.
Encourage the person to take their prescribed insulin. Seek medical help if symptoms worsen.
Have the person use their prescribed inhaler. Encourage slow, deep breaths. Seek medical help if symptoms persist.

patterns: difficulty breathing after exposure to allergen
response: Administer antihistamines if available. Seek medical help if symptoms worsen.
Remove the person from water immediately. Begin CPR if trained. Seek emergency medical help.
Turn off the power source if safe to do so. Do not touch the person until the power is off. Seek emergency medical help.
Call emergency services immediately. Provide information on the substance ingested. Do not leave the person alone.
Call emergency services immediately. Keep the person awake and sitting up if possible.
Encourage the person to drink water or oral rehydration solutions. Seek medical help if symptoms persist.
Move the person to a cooler place. Offer cool water. Apply cool compresses.

Seasonal influenza, including H1N1, typically peaks during the monsoon and post-monsoon months in India. It's essential to get vaccinated and practice good hygiene to prevent its spread.
Dengue fever is prevalent during the monsoon season in India. Preventive measures include eliminating mosquito breeding sites and using mosquito repellents.
Malaria transmission is highest during the monsoon season in India. Preventive measures include using insecticide-treated bed nets and taking antimalarial medications as prescribed.
Chikungunya is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is common during the monsoon season. Preventive measures include eliminating mosquito breeding sites and using mosquito repellents.
Heatstroke is a serious condition that can occur during extreme heat. Preventive measures include staying hydrated, avoiding direct sunlight, and wearing light-colored clothing.
Seasonal allergies are common during the spring and autumn months in India. Managing allergies includes avoiding known allergens and using antihistamines as prescribed.
Air pollution, especially during winter, can exacerbate respiratory conditions. Limiting outdoor activities and wearing masks can help reduce exposure.
Waterborne diseases are prevalent during the monsoon season in India. Preventive measures include drinking boiled or filtered water and practicing good hygiene.
Vector-borne diseases are common during the monsoon season in India. Preventive measures include using insect repellents and avoiding contact with animals.
Tuberculosis cases in India show seasonal variation, with increased incidence during the cooler months. Early diagnosis and adherence to treatment are crucial.
Pneumonia cases in India often increase during the winter months. Preventive measures include vaccination and avoiding exposure to cold air.
Hepatitis E outbreaks are common during the monsoon season in India due to water contamination. Preventive measures include drinking boiled or filtered water and practicing good hygiene.
Swine flu, caused by the H1N1 virus, can occur year-round in India. Preventive measures include vaccination and practicing good hygiene.
Bird flu outbreaks are rare but can occur in India. Preventive measures include avoiding contact with sick poultry and following health advisories.
Hand, foot, and mouth disease is common among children in India. Preventive measures include good hand hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected individuals.
The dengue vaccine is available in India for individuals aged 9-45 years. Consult a healthcare provider to determine eligibility.
The malaria vaccine is not yet widely available in India. Preventive measures include using insecticide-treated bed nets and taking antimalarial medications as prescribed.
There is no vaccine for chikungunya currently available in India. Preventive measures include eliminating mosquito breeding sites and using mosquito repellents.
Preventive measures for heatstroke include staying hydrated, avoiding direct sunlight, and wearing light-colored clothing. Seek medical attention if symptoms persist.
Managing seasonal allergies includes avoiding known allergens, using antihistamines as prescribed, and keeping windows closed during high pollen seasons.
Exposure to high levels of air pollution can lead to respiratory issues. Limiting outdoor activities and wearing masks can help reduce exposure.
Preventive measures include drinking boiled or filtered water, practicing good hygiene, and avoiding consumption of raw or undercooked food.
Eliminating mosquito breeding sites, using insect repellents, and wearing protective clothing can help prevent vector-borne diseases.
Preventive measures include vaccination with the BCG vaccine, early diagnosis, and adherence to prescribed treatment regimens.
Vaccination, avoiding exposure to cold air, and maintaining good respiratory hygiene can help prevent pneumonia.
Preventive measures include drinking boiled or filtered water, practicing good hygiene, and avoiding consumption of raw or undercooked food.
Preventive measures include vaccination, practicing good hygiene, and avoiding close contact with infected individuals.
Preventive measures include avoiding contact with sick poultry, following health advisories, and practicing good hygiene.

patterns: hand foot mouth disease prevention India
response: Preventive measures include good hand hygiene, avoiding close contact with infected individuals, and keeping children's toys clean.
Consult a healthcare provider to determine eligibility for the dengue vaccine, as it is available for individuals aged 9-45 years.

In India, children should receive vaccines like BCG, Hepatitis B, DPT, Polio, Hib, PCV, Rotavirus, MMR, Varicella, Hepatitis A, Typhoid, HPV, MCV, and Influenza as per the Indian Academy of Pediatrics schedule to protect against various diseases.

A balanced diet for children includes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and dairy. Limiting processed foods and sugary drinks can help prevent childhood obesity, which is projected to nearly double in the next 20 years in India.
Encouraging outdoor play, sports, and limiting screen time to less than two hours per day can promote physical activity in children and reduce the risk of obesity and related health issues.
Regular brushing with fluoride toothpaste, limiting sugary snacks, and scheduling dental check-ups can help maintain good oral hygiene and prevent dental problems in children.
Establishing a consistent bedtime routine, ensuring a comfortable sleep environment, and limiting caffeine and screen time before bed can improve sleep quality in children.
Elderly individuals should engage in regular physical activity, maintain a balanced diet, avoid tobacco and excessive alcohol, and seek regular medical check-ups to promote healthy aging.
Maintaining social connections, engaging in mentally stimulating activities, and seeking professional help when needed can support mental health in elderly individuals.
A diet rich in fiber, lean proteins, fruits, vegetables, and low in sodium and saturated fats can help meet the nutritional needs of elderly individuals and prevent chronic diseases.
Regular physical activity, such as walking, yoga, or strength training, can improve mobility, balance, and overall health in elderly individuals, reducing the risk of falls.
Establishing a regular sleep schedule, creating a comfortable sleep environment, and avoiding stimulants before bedtime can improve sleep quality in elderly individuals.
Elderly individuals should receive vaccines like the annual flu vaccine, pneumococcal vaccine, and shingles vaccine as recommended by healthcare providers to prevent infections.
Maintaining a balanced diet, taking prenatal vitamins, engaging in regular physical activity, and attending regular prenatal check-ups are essential for a healthy pregnancy.
Taking folic acid supplements at least two months before conception and during early pregnancy can reduce the risk of neural tube defects by up to 80%.
Monitoring blood sugar levels, maintaining a healthy diet, and engaging in regular physical activity can help manage and prevent gestational diabetes during pregnancy.
Regular prenatal check-ups, monitoring for signs of complications, and following healthcare provider recommendations can help manage and prevent pregnancy complications.
Seeking support for postpartum depression, engaging in gentle physical activity, and receiving breastfeeding assistance can aid in recovery after childbirth.
Breastfeeding provides essential nutrients and antibodies to infants. Seeking guidance on latching techniques and positions can enhance the breastfeeding experience.

patterns: mental health support for pregnant women
response: Seeking mental health support, practicing stress management techniques, and maintaining social connections can support emotional well-being during pregnancy.
Engaging in safe exercises like walking and prenatal yoga can improve physical health during pregnancy. Always consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new exercise regimen.
Consulting with a healthcare provider before traveling, staying hydrated, and avoiding travel to areas with high health risks can ensure safe travel during pregnancy.
Consuming a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, and avoiding certain foods like unpasteurized dairy and high-mercury fish, can support a healthy pregnancy.

patterns: preventing excessive weight gain during pregnancy
response: Following healthcare provider recommendations for weight gain, maintaining a balanced diet, and engaging in regular physical activity can help manage weight during pregnancy.
Using pillows for support, sleeping on the left side, and establishing a bedtime routine can improve sleep quality during pregnancy.

patterns: skin care tips for pregnant women
response: Using moisturizers, staying hydrated, and protecting skin from sun exposure can help manage skin changes during pregnancy.

patterns: when to seek medical help during pregnancy
response: Recognizing warning signs like severe headaches, vision changes, or abdominal pain and seeking timely medical attention can help manage pregnancy complications.
Maintaining a healthy lifestyle, taking prenatal vitamins, and consulting with a healthcare provider can prepare the body for a healthy pregnancy.
Regular prenatal check-ups, maintaining a healthy diet, and engaging in physical activity can help prevent common pregnancy complications.
Seeking support from partners, family, and community resources can provide emotional and practical assistance during pregnancy.

patterns: I don't know if I can keep going

I'm feeling like I'm not making a difference
I'm feeling like I'm not moving forward
response: You are more than enough. Your worth isn't defined by challenges but by your courage to face them.

patterns: I'm feeling like I'm not making a difference
I'm feeling like I'm not achieving anything
I'm feeling like I'm not living up to expectations
response: Purpose can be found in the smallest moments. Let's explore together.

patterns: I'm not taking time for myself
response: Self-love is essential. Be kind to yourself, and remember that you deserve compassion.

patterns: I'm not focusing on my strengths
response: Your strengths are unique to you. Embrace them, and use them to navigate challenges.

patterns: I'm feeling overwhelmed by my thoughts
response: Clarity comes with time. Be patient with yourself, and trust that answers will come.

patterns: I'm feeling like I'm not enough
I'm feeling like I'm not achieving anything
response: Anxiety is a natural response. Take deep breaths, and focus on the present moment.

patterns: I'm feeling like I'm not enough
I'm feeling like I'm not achieving anything
I'm feeling like I'm not living up to expectations
response: You are seen, you are heard, and you matter.

patterns: I'm not sure I can trust anyone
I'm not sure I should talk about this
I feel like no one cares
response: This is a safe space. You're not alone, and I'm here to support you.
